questions.name: Process is repeatable, standardized rules executed by humans supported by technology to perform value adding tasks.
questions.Driver: Operations is area of management concerned with planning and executing of processes that deal with the production of goods and services
questions.Des1: Vertical integration is defined as the integration of the different OT & IT systems at different hierarchical levels of a production system within a factory (e.g., actuator and sensor, controller, production management, facility management, manufacturing, execution, and corporate planning levels ) into an end-to-end network.
questions.Des2: Industry 4.0 optimizes factory operations to be flexible, adaptable, and dynamic through decentralized planning and execution (e.g. customized batch sizes). End-to-end system visibility will be possible with the seamless transfer and exchange of data between enterprise systems and operations (shopfloor & facility) systems.

options.name: Not defined
options.descp: The process steps (e.g. production scheduling, energy consumption etc.) are not explicitly defined or tracked. (e.g. production is an unpredictable process)

options.name: Analog
options.descp: The process steps are defined and completed by humans using analog tools. (e.g. production count tracked on paper ledger)

options.name: Digital
options.descp: The process steps are defined and completed by humans using digital tools. (e.g. using ERP, MES, SCADA software)

options.name: Automated or Integrated
options.descp: The process steps are defined, digital and automated or integrated requiring n human interaction. (e.g. a verified incoming order is automatically scheduled for production)

options.name: Integrated and Automated
options.descp: The process steps are defined, digital, automated and securely integrated with the prior / subsequent steps across all automation pyramid levels. (e.g. common interfaces & standardized protocols enable interoperability across the hierarchy level with dataflow among processes)

options.name: Intelligent
options.descp: The process steps are defined, digital, automated, securely integrated and intelligently decide how to best optimize the production performance. Furthermore, resources such as energy and material will be used more efficiently, which enables extremely flexible, easily adaptable production processes. (e.g. predictive maintenance schedules system maintenance pre-emptively before a critical failure)

questions.name: Process is repeatable, standardized rules executed by humans supported by technology to perform value adding tasks.
questions.Driver: Supply chain describes area of management concerned with the flow of goods and services from the point of origin to the point of consumption
questions.Des1: Horizontal integration is defined as the integration of various systems for the support and/or execution of the different value processes (e.g. manufacturing, logistics, marketing, engineering, services etc.) both within and beyond company limits into an end-to-end network.
questions.Des2: Industry 4.0 optimize the flow of material and information along the value chain including customer integration. End-to-end system visibility will be possible with the seamless transfer and exchange of data between enterprise systems and operations (shopfloor & facility) systems.

options.name: Not defined
options.descp: The supply chain steps (e.g. component ordering from suppliers) are not explicitly defined. (e.g. the supply chain is an unpredictable process)

options.name: Analog
options.descp: The supply chain steps are defined and completed by humans using analog tools. (e.g. an employee calls the logistics department when a shipment is ready for pickup)

options.name: Digital
options.descp: The supply chain steps are defined and completed by humans using digital tools. (e.g. planning of component inventories to be ordered from suppliers is done using IT systems)

options.name: Automated or Integrated
options.descp: The supply chain steps are defined, digital and automated or integrated requiring minimum human interaction (e.g. if inventories of components fall, the IT system automatically informs purchasing that new components need to be ordered)

options.name: Integrated and Automated
options.descp: The supply chain steps are defined, digital, automated and securely integrated with the prior / subsequent partners/steps. (e.g. the logistics company is notified by an IT system when an order from a customer is ready for shipping pickup)

options.name: Intelligent
options.descp: The supply chain steps are defined, digital, automated, securely integrated and intelligently decide how best to optimize the supply chain. (e.g. big data analytics predict rising customer demand for a given product and the preparation steps to handle this situation are automatically triggered)

questions.name: Process is repeatable, standardized rules executed by humans supported by technology to perform value adding tasks.
questions.Driver: Product lifecycle is area of managing the entire lifecycle of a product from inception, through engineering design and manufacture, to the service and disposal.
questions.Des1: The life cycle of a product is defined as its development as well as engineering of the corresponding production system, the manufacturing of the product by the production system, the use of the manufactured product by the user, and the product's recycling and/or dismantling.
questions.Des2: Industry 4.0 aims to create digital representations of the product and production (also called 'digital twin').
questions.Des3: The digital representations are created, refined and enriched throughout all stages of the engineering process. For example, the 'Production Planning' creates the digital twin of the production, the 'Production Engineering' refines it and the 'Production Execution' enriches it with real-time operational data.

options.name: Not defined
options.descp: The engineering process steps (e.g. product design) are not explicitly defined as an official process. (i.e. engineering is an unpredictable process)

options.name: Analog
options.descp: The engineering process steps are defined and completed by humans using analog tools. (e.g. product designs are drawn with pen & paper, basic lean manufacturing principles are applied in designing the production flow)

options.name: Digital
options.descp: The engineering process steps are defined and completed by humans using digital tools. (e.g. using computer aided design software to create, refine and enrich the digital twin)

options.name: Automated or Integrated
options.descp: The engineering process steps are defined, digital and automated or integrated requiring minimum human interaction (e.g. digital plant simulations automatically evaluate & optimize production designs for performance)

options.name: Integrated and Automated
options.descp: The engineering process steps are defined, digital, automated, & securely integrated with the prior / subsequent steps. (e.g. relevant digital data from the product design stage is passed, with little delay & loss, digitally to the production planning stage

options.name: Intelligent
options.descp: The engineering process steps are defined, digital, automated, securely integrated and intelligently decide how best to optimize each stage. (e.g. big data analytics identify product features relevant for customers purchasing choices and optimize the engineering process)

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Automation is the application of technology to monitor, control and execute the production and delivery of product and services.
questions.Des1: Shop Floor Automation in the context of Industry 4.0 aims to drive the following:
questions.Des4: 3. Human collaboration and optimize task allocation (TA) between humans and automation for complex tasks

options.name: None
options.descp: The shop floor processes are not automated. (i.e. all shop floor processes are executed by humans)

options.name: Basic
options.descp: The shop floor processes are automated with significant human operator’s inputs. (i.e. sensors, actuators, RFID, barcode, displays etc. are used)

options.name: Advanced
options.descp: The shop floor processes are automated with minimum human operator’s inputs (i.e. sensor, actuators, RFID, barcode, displays and displays are governed by standalone controllers)

options.name: Full
options.descp: The shop floor processes are automated with no human interventions. (i.e. automated cells work)

options.name: Flexible
options.descp: The shop floor processes are automated and are implemented using configurable plug and play automation components enabling quick changeovers.(e.g. automation components can be recombined for a given production tasks quickly and easily)

options.name: Converged
options.descp: The shop floor processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state. Shop floor level automation is converged with enterprise level and facility level into best of collaborative automation systems.

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Automation is the application of technology to monitor, control and execute the production and delivery of product and services.
questions.Des1: The automation of enterprise level is enabled by automated processing of the value creation processes through enterprise systems with nearly zero downtime.
questions.Des2: These processes should be performed more efficiently, real time and adaptable. People are relieved of non-creative tasks, increase in productivity, and resource efficiency.

options.name: None
options.descp: The enterprise processes are not automated. (i.e. all enterprise processes are executed by humans)

options.name: Basic
options.descp: The enterprise processes are automated with significant human operator’s inputs. (e.g. using manufacturing execution system software to automatically retrieve production KPIs)

options.name: Advanced
options.descp: The enterprise processes are automated with minimum human operators’ inputs. (e.g. ERP, CRM, QMS, MES etc. talk through adapters and human operators validate inputs are correct)

options.name: Full
options.descp: The enterprise processes are automated with no human interventions (e.g. manufacturing execution and enterprise resource planning are fully automated)

options.name: Flexible
options.descp: The enterprise processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state.

options.name: Converged
options.descp: The enterprise processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state. Enterprise level automation is converged with shop floor level and facility level into best of collaborative automation systems.

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Connectivity is the state of interconnection and interoperability of platforms, systems and applications in a secure environment to enable seamless data exchange.
questions.Des1: Automation in a facility enables the efficient utilization of resources (machines, energy, etc.) in production where the systems autonomously exchange information, trigger actions and control each other independently
questions.Des2: This is achieved via automated assessment of a machine or condition of a system based on defined parameters such as temperature or condition.

options.name: None
options.descp: The facility processes are not automated. (i.e. all facility processes are executed by humans)

options.name: Basic
options.descp: The facility processes are automated with significant human operator’s inputs. (e.g. environmental sensors such as humidity, temperature and meters for consumed utilities such as water, air, gas, electricity is installed & managed by humans)

options.name: Advanced
options.descp: The facility processes are automated with minimum human operator’s inputs. (e.g. utilities meters and sensor data can be captured by controllers and BMS systems)

options.name: Full
options.descp: The facility processes are automated with no human intervention. (e.g. all utilities meters and sensor data can be captured by controllers and BMS systems)

options.name: Flexible
options.descp: The facility processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state.

options.name: Converged
options.descp: The facility processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state. Facility level automation is converged with shop floor level and enterprise level into best of collaborative automation systems.

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Connectivity is the state of interconnection and interoperability of platforms, systems and applications in a secure environment to enable seamless data exchange.
questions.Des1: Shop floor connectivity enables seamless secure data sharing and interoperability between machines and across shop floor

options.name: None
options.descp: There is no connectivity between shop floor automation systems.

options.name: Connected
options.descp: The shop floor automation systems are connected. There are numerous communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more heterogeneous and but without interoperable landscape. (e.g. PROFINET, PROFIBUS, EtherCAT, OPC UA)

options.name: Connected & Interoperable
options.descp: The shop floor automation systems are connected and interoperable. There are few communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more homogeneous & interoperable landscape. (e.g. mostly only PROFINET)

options.name: Secure
options.descp: The shop floor automation systems are connected, interoperable and exhibit high security capabilities with high resilience to threats. (e.g. authentication, encryption)

options.name: Real Time or Scalable
options.descp: The shopfloor automation systems are connected, interoperable, secure and are capable of real-time communication or scalable for integrated networking. (e.g. PLC unit on real-time “Time Sensitive Network” on Ethernet)

options.name: Real-Time and Scalable
options.descp: The facility processes are automated and data processing for changing environment conditions in real-time state. Facility level automation is converged with shop floor level and enterprise level into best of collaborative automation systems.

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Connectivity is the state of interconnection and interoperability of platforms, systems and applications in a secure environment to enable seamless data exchange.
questions.Des1: Enterprise application and network connectivity enables seamless secure data sharing and interoperability between enterprise, facility infrastructure and across shop floor.

options.name: None
options.descp: There is no connectivity between enterprise IT systems.

options.name: Connected
options.descp: The enterprise IT systems are connected. There are numerous communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more heterogeneous but without interoperable landscape. (e.g. Office LAN, PROFINET, OPC UA)

options.name: Connected & Interoperable
options.descp: The enterprise IT systems are connected. There are few communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more homogeneous & interoperable landscape. (e.g. mostly only Office LAN, OPC UA)

options.name: Secure
options.descp: The enterprise IT systems are connected, interoperable and exhibit high security capabilities with high resilience to threats. (e.g. authentication, encryption)

options.name: Real Time or Scalable
options.descp: The enterprise IT systems are connected, interoperable, secure and are capable of real-time communication or scalable for integrated networking. (e.g. router unit on real-time “Time Sensitive Network” on Ethernet)

options.name: Real Time and Scalable
options.descp: The enterprise IT systems are connected, interoperable, secure and scalable in real-time communication with sematic understanding. (e.g. self initialization and loading of applications in production environment )” on Ethernet)

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Connectivity is the state of interconnection and interoperability of platforms, systems and applications in a secure environment to enable seamless data exchange.
questions.Des1: Facility sensors and devices connectivity enables seamless secure data sharing and interoperability between facility infrastructure and across shop floor.
questions.Des2: An effective, efficient and relevant facility and resource (e.g. energy, water and waste) integration strategy can help in controlling facility/ consumption cost, which are one of the largest expenditures in asset-intensive enterprise.

options.name: None
options.descp: There is no connectivity between facility automation systems.

options.name: Connected
options.descp: The facility systems are connected. There are numerous communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more heterogeneous but without interoperable landscape. (e.g. Modbus, DNP, EtherCAT, OPC UA)

options.name: Connected & Interoperable
options.descp: The facility systems are connected. There are few communication technologies & protocols in use creating a more homogeneous & interoperable landscape. (e.g. mostly only DNP3)

options.name: Secure
options.descp: The facility systems are connected, interoperable and exhibit high security capabilities with high resilience to threats. (e.g. authentication, encryption)

options.name: Real Time or Scalable
options.descp: The facility systems are connected, interoperable, secure and are capable of real-time communication or scalable for integrated networking. (e.g. energy meter on real-time “Time Sensitive Network” on Ethernet)

options.name: Real Time and Scalable
options.descp: The facility systems are connected, interoperable, secure scalable in real-time communication with sematic understanding. (e.g. self-identifying energy meter or temperature unit)

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Intelligence is utilization of data through analytics to create new actionable applications and functionalities.
questions.Des1: Intelligence leads to new functionalities in production system with significantly reduced intervention by human.
questions.Des2: Intelligent shop floor automation systems are adaptive (they interact with their environment and adapt to it individually), robust (constantly changing environment without any reduction in performance levels) and, forward looking (they anticipate the effects of different factors based on experience-based knowledge).
questions.Des3: By applying real- time production process data monitoring, analysis and processing, intelligent automation systems would be informative and able to make real time decision, predict future production (self- learning) trend and reacts autonomously to changes or faults and takes appropriate actions.

options.name: None
options.descp: No automation & IT systems are in use.

options.name: Computerized
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that they simply execute (not more than that).

options.name: Visible
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies and hence are aware of deviations from the defined target state) Operators are notified of errors and failures.

options.name: Transparent
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor and diagnose. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to understand why they occur)

options.name: Predictive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose and predict. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to forecast future states of the system)

options.name: Adaptive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose, predict and adapt itself to optimize. (e.g. system performance and minimize errors/anomalies)

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Intelligence is utilization of data through analytics to create new actionable applications and functionalities.
questions.Des1: By applying real- time production process data monitoring, analysis and processing, enterprise would be informative and able to make real time decision, predict future production (self- learning) trend and reacts autonomously to changes or faults and takes appropriate actions.

options.name: None
options.descp: No automation & IT systems are in use.

options.name: Computerized
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that they simply execute (not more than that).

options.name: Visible
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies and hence are aware of deviations from the defined target state) Operators are notified of errors and failures.

options.name: Transparent
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor and diagnose. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to understand why they occur)

options.name: Predictive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose and predict. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to forecast future states of the system)

options.name: Adaptive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose, predict and adapt itself to optimize. (e.g. system performance and minimize errors/anomalies)

questions.name: Technology are machines, tools and systems (includes both hardware and software) that are deployed for the production of goods and services
questions.Driver: Intelligence is utilization of data through analytics to create new actionable applications and functionalities.
questions.Des1: Intelligence leads to new functionalities in production system with significantly reduced intervention by human.
questions.Des2: Intelligent facility automation systems are adaptive (they interact with their environment and adapt to it individually), robust (constantly changing environment without any reduction in performance levels) and, forward looking (they anticipate the effects of different factors based on experience-based knowledge).
questions.Des3: By applying real- time production process data monitoring, analysis and processing, intelligent automation systems would be informative and able to make real time decision, predict future production (self- learning) trend and reacts autonomously to changes or faults and takes appropriate actions.

options.name: None
options.descp: No automation & IT systems are in use.

options.name: Computerized
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that they simply execute (not more than that).

options.name: Visible
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies and hence are aware of deviations from the defined target state) Operators are notified of errors and failures.

options.name: Transparent
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor and diagnose. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to understand why they occur)

options.name: Predictive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose and predict. (e.g. system performance and errors/anomalies to forecast future states of the system)

options.name: Adaptive
options.descp: The automation & IT systems have runtime logic that can monitor, diagnose, predict and adapt itself to optimize. (e.g. system performance and minimize errors/anomalies)

questions.name: The organization governs the long term perspective of the company.
questions.Driver: Talent Readiness describes workforce’s ability to run, manage, and continuously enhance a highly digitalized factory/plant
questions.Des1: Clear training and development plan must exist for all employees to promote flexibility and continuous improvement.
questions.Des2: In a Cyber Physical World, company can generates enormous amount of data but ultimately it will be dependent on people to process the data and develop appropriate action (e.g. intelligent runtime logic, decision –making and etc.).
questions.Des3: Employees across all levels of organization (i.e. shopfloor, facility & enterprise) must be carefully hired, trained and developed in respect to digitalization (e.g. digital technologies such as data analytics).

options.name: No Understanding
options.descp: No Clear Training and development plan (e.g. skills matrix for operators, lean manufacturing for engineers etc.) exist in the company. Workforce at all levels of the organization is not aware of Industry 4.0 and no efforts is made to identify & understand key digital capabilities across the organization have been made.

options.name: Basic Understanding
options.descp: Ad-hoc Training and development process exist in the company but not up to date with company transformation strategy. Workforce at all levels of the organization is aware of digital tools and limited efforts are made to identify & understand key digital capabilities by individual teams of the organization.

options.name: Full Understanding
options.descp: Clear Training and development plan exist in the company and up to date with the company transformation strategy. Workforce at all levels of the organization has been informed and understood about the company's plan for skills uptake on digital tools and there is an organized effort to identify key digital capabilities in key areas.

options.name: Planning
options.descp: Key digital capabilities are identified, and formal training plans are being developed for workforce at all levels of the organization.

options.name: Executing
options.descp: Key digital capabilities are identified, training plans have been developed and at the stage of implementation for workforce at all levels of the organization.

options.name: Sustaining
options.descp: Key digital capabilities are identified, training plans exist and are ongoing for workforce at all levels of the organization. The working environment is monitored for continuous improvement on digital skills uptake.

questions.name: The organization governs the long term perspective of the company.
questions.Driver: Talent Readiness describes workforce’s ability to run, manage, and continuously enhance a highly digitalized factory/plant
questions.Des1: With increasing complexity, hierarchy, structure and subject matter expertise of leaders will become less important. The need for flexibility and speed requires decentral organizational forms and leaders´ capabilities to delegate responsibilities . An Industry 4.0 leadership requires the knowledge of I4.0 concepts and its translation to their enterprise and its resulting requirements to the management teams.

options.name: No Understanding
options.descp: Management team is not familiar with Industry 4.0 concepts (e.g. vertical integration, value chain) and acts in formalized structures and processes.

options.name: Limited Understanding
options.descp: Management team is familiar with Industry 4.0 concepts but have not rationalized them for their operation. Still acts in formalized structures and processes.

options.name: Full Understanding
options.descp: Management team fully understands Industry 4.0 concepts and is capable to prepare change management plan. Allows input from teams.

options.name: Planning
options.descp: Management team can show evidence of change management plan. Actively engages teams.

options.name: Executing
options.descp: Management team fosters a business transformation environment and shows clear roadmap for implementation of business transformation. Delegates responsibilities and empowers teams.

options.name: Sustaining
options.descp: Management team is agile, responsive, drives transformation process in a sustainable way and is highly connected with enterprise network. Inspires sustainable high-performance teams.

questions.name: The organization governs the long term perspective of the company.
questions.Driver: Structure & Management is the framework that guides how teams act/ interact and initiatives are implemented to achieve organizational goals.
questions.Des1: Employees across all levels of organization must be prepared for a new way of working in the new age of digitalization. Faster and tighter development iterations with quick decision enablement are important.

options.name: Disconnected
options.descp: Work is in silos, teams are sanctioned and assigned formally by management, interaction and communication are limited & controlled.

options.name: Connected
options.descp: Work is primarily in silos, team are sanctioned and assigned formally by management, cross functional interaction, communication is on ad hoc basis.

options.name: Functional
options.descp: Key efforts are delivered via formal cross functional teams, some ad hoc problem solving initiative taken by departments; internal focus.

options.name: Solution-Oriented
options.descp: Cross functional collaboration & teamwork is realized as part of solutions orientation.

options.name: Open
options.descp: Cross functional collaboration & teamwork is realized as part of solutions orientation; engagement with external partners growing & seen as value-creation.

options.name: Dynamic
options.descp: Cross-functional collaboration and teamwork is realized as part of solutions orientation; engagement with external supply chain growing seen a value-creation activity, teams are working with an appropriate level of autonomy and various suitable communication paths exist.

questions.name: The organization governs the long term perspective of the company.
questions.Driver: Structure & Management is the framework that guides how teams act/ interact and initiatives are implemented to achieve organizational goals.
questions.Des1: Industry 4.0 requires strategy, policy and governance framework to be in place across all levels of organizations (i.e. shopfloor, facility and enterprise) to drive change management in the industry level transformation.

options.name: Not existence
options.descp: No strategy, policy and governance for Industry 4.0 initiative exists.

options.name: Defined
options.descp: Strategy and policy framework are defined /documented and governance committee is established.

options.name: Clarified
options.descp: Goles and responsibilities for delivering the policy objective are clear and understood by stakeholders, and partners.

options.name: Integrated
options.descp: Policy plan is integrated into departmental planning process and influences overall organizational strategy and direction.

options.name: Implemented
options.descp: Policy Plan is formally implemented in the company and governed with a standardized approach and framework.  This includes the Industrial Safety and Security principles during the transformation. Management monitor outcomes-focused metrics by which processes, staff, and outcomes are measured to ensure that goals are being met..

options.name: Transformed
options.descp: Industry 4.0 services/products and channels drive the organizational structure and reporting within a standardized policy and governance.
